name: Titanium.IOStream
doc:
@platform android 1.7 @platform iphone 1.7 @platform ipad 1.7 @platform mobileweb 1.8 @editurl https://github.com/appcelerator/titanium_mobile/edit/master/apidoc/Titanium/IOStream.yml

IOStream is the interface that all stream types implement.

@description

See the Titanium.Stream module for related utility methods that support asynchronous I/O.

Examples

Write Data to a Stream

This example demonstrates writing data to a stream.

var outBuffer = Ti.createBuffer({data: "write me"});
// stream object could be socket, file, buffer or blob
var outStream = Ti.Stream.createStream({mode: Ti.Stream.MODE_WRITE});

var bytesWritten = outStream.write(outBuffer);  // writes entire buffer to stream
Ti.API.info("Bytes written:" + bytesWritten);  // should be 8

bytesWritten = outStream.write(outBuffer, 2, 5);  // only writes "ite m" to stream
Ti.API.info("Bytes written:" + bytesWritten);  // should be 5

Read Data From a Stream

This shows a simple example of reading data from a stream, one buffer full at a time. 

var size = 0;
// read data one buffer full at a time
while ((size = instream.read(buffer)) > -1) {
    // do something with the data here ...
    Ti.API.info("Read " + size + " bytes.");
}

Read Data With Offset and Length

This example shows how to read data from a stream into a buffer. We assume that the inStream variable holds a previously initialized stream that contains the string, "World Titanium".

var inBuffer = Ti.createBuffer({ value: "Hello [           ]" });

// Read the first 6 bytes from the stream to the buffer, starting at position 10.
var bytesRead = inStream.read(inBuffer, 10, 6);

Ti.API.info("Bytes read: " + bytesRead);
Ti.API.info(inBuffer.toString());

// Read the next 8  bytes from the stream to the buffer, starting at position 8.
bytesRead = inStream.read(inBuffer, 8, 8);

Ti.API.info("Bytes read: " + bytesRead);
Ti.API.info(inBuffer.toString());

The second read overwrites the data from the first read, so the output looks like this:

[INFO] Bytes read: 6
[INFO] Hello [   World   ]
[INFO] Bytes read: 8
[INFO] Hello [ Titanium  ]

property.name: apiName
property.doc:
The name of the API that this proxy corresponds to.

@description

The value of this property is the fully qualified name of the API. For example, Button returns Ti.UI.Button.

@platform android 3.2.0 @platform blackberry 3.2.0 @platform iphone 3.2.0 @platform ipad 3.2.0 @platform mobileweb 3.2.0
property.shortDoc: The name of the API that this proxy corresponds to. ...

property.name: bubbleParent
property.doc:
Indicates if the proxy will bubble an event to its parent.

@description

Some proxies (most commonly views) have a relationship to other proxies, often established by the add() method. For example, for a button added to a window, a click event on the button would bubble up to the window. Other common parents are table sections to their rows, table views to their sections, and scrollable views to their views. Set this property to false to disable the bubbling to the proxy's parent.

@platform android 3.0.0 @platform iphone 3.0.0 @platform ipad 3.0.0
property.shortDoc: Indicates if the proxy will bubble an event to its parent. ...

property.name: lifecycleContainer
property.doc:
The Window or TabGroup whose Activity lifecycle should be triggered on the proxy.

@description

If this property is set to a Window or TabGroup, then the corresponding Activity lifecycle event callbacks will also be called on the proxy. Proxies that require the activity lifecycle will need this property set to the appropriate containing Window or TabGroup.

@platform android 3.6.0
property.shortDoc: The Window or TabGroup whose Activity lifecycle should be triggered on the proxy. ...

method.name: addEventListener
method.doc: Adds the specified callback as an event listener for the named event.

params.name: callback
params.doc: Callback function to invoke when the event is fired.

method.shortDoc: Adds the specified callback as an event listener for the named event. ...

method.name: applyProperties
method.doc:
Applies the properties to the proxy.

@description

Properties are supplied as a dictionary. Each key-value pair in the object is applied to the proxy such that myproxy[key] = value.

params.name: props
params.doc:
A dictionary of properties to apply.

@platform android 3.0.0 @platform blackberry 3.3.0 @platform iphone 3.0.0 @platform ipad 3.0.0 @platform mobileweb 3.0.0

method.shortDoc: Applies the properties to the proxy. ...

method.name: close
method.doc:
Closes this stream.

@description

Throws an exception on error.

method.name: fireEvent
method.doc: Fires a synthesized event to any registered listeners.

params.name: event
params.doc: A dictionary of keys and values to add to the Titanium.Event object sent to the listeners.

method.shortDoc: Fires a synthesized event to any registered listeners. ...

method.name: getApiName
method.doc: Gets the value of the apiName property.
method.shortDoc: Gets the value of the apiName property. ...

method.name: getBubbleParent
method.doc: Gets the value of the bubbleParent property.
method.shortDoc: Gets the value of the bubbleParent property. ...

method.name: getLifecycleContainer
method.doc: Gets the value of the lifecycleContainer property.
method.shortDoc: Gets the value of the lifecycleContainer property. ...

method.name: isReadable

return.name: return
return.doc: True if stream is readable, false otherwise.

method.shortDoc: Indicates whether this stream is readable. ...

method.name: isWriteable

return.name: return
return.doc: True if stream is writeable, false otherwise.

method.shortDoc: Indicates whether this stream is writeable. ...

method.name: read
method.doc:
Reads data from this stream into a buffer.

@description

If offset and length are specified, data is written into the buffer starting at position offset. Data is read from this stream until one of the following occurs:

  • the end of this stream is reached
  • the end of the buffer is reached
  • a total of length bytes have been read from the stream

If offset and length are omitted, data is written starting at the beginning of the buffer.

Returns the number of bytes read, or -1 if the end of stream was reached before any data was read.

Throws an exception on error. For example, if the offset value is past the last byte of buffer.

This method is synchronous. To perform an asynchronous read on an IOStream, use Titanium.Stream.read.

params.name: offset
params.doc: Offset into the buffer to start writing stream data. If specified, length must also be specified.

params.name: length
params.doc: Maximum number of bytes to read. If specified, offset must also be specified.

method.shortDoc: Reads data from this stream into a buffer. ...

method.name: removeEventListener
method.doc:
Removes the specified callback as an event listener for the named event.

@description

Multiple listeners can be registered for the same event, so the callback parameter is used to determine which listener to remove.

When adding a listener, you must save a reference to the callback function in order to remove the listener later:

var listener = function() { Ti.API.info("Event listener called."); }
window.addEventListener('click', listener);

To remove the listener, pass in a reference to the callback function:

window.removeEventListener('click', listener);

params.name: callback
params.doc: Callback function to remove. Must be the same function passed to addEventListener.

method.shortDoc: Removes the specified callback as an event listener for the named event. ...

method.name: setBubbleParent
method.doc: Sets the value of the bubbleParent property.

params.name: bubbleParent
params.doc:
New value for the property.

@platform android 3.0.0 @platform iphone 3.0.0 @platform ipad 3.0.0

method.shortDoc: Sets the value of the bubbleParent property. ...

method.name: setLifecycleContainer
method.doc: Sets the value of the lifecycleContainer property.
method.shortDoc: Sets the value of the lifecycleContainer property. ...

method.name: write
method.doc:
Writes data from a buffer to this stream.

@description

If offset and length are specified, data is read from the buffer starting at offset. Bytes are read from the buffer and written to the stream until:

  • the end of the buffer is reached
  • length bytes have been written
  • the stream returns an error

If offset and length are omitted, all of the data in the buffer is written to this stream.

Returns the number of bytes actually written.

Throws an exception if an error is encountered.

params.name: offset
params.doc: Offset in the buffer of the first byte to write to the stream. If specified, length must also be specified.

params.name: length
params.doc: Maximum number of bytes to write to the stream. If specified, offset must also be specified.

method.shortDoc: Writes data from a buffer to this stream. ...
